questions.question_text: Which two types of devices are included in the conditionally trusted endpoints category of Cisco UCM? (Choose two.)

choices.D: The DNS servers are unreachable from the Cisco UCM server.
choices.C: The DNS server has multiple PTR records for the Cisco UCM servers.
choices.B: A failure is expected when the utils diagnose test command is run on a subscriber.
choices.A: The DNS server is missing PTR records for the Cisco UCM servers.
choices.E: The firewall is blocking UDP port 53 traffic from Cisco UCM to the DNS servers.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
Based on the output DNS server is reachable, do it should be A and C. If you have PTR pointing to multiple hosts the you'll get the same error as with no PTR configured.

questions.question_text: What are two functions of Cisco Expressway in the Collaboration Edge? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Expressway-E provides a VPN entry point for Cisco IP phones with a Cisco AnyConnect client using authentication based on certificates.
choices.D: The Expressway-C and Expressway-E pair can interconnect H.323-to-SIP calls for voice.
choices.E: The Expressway-C and Expressway-E pair can enable connectivity from the corporate network to the PSTN via a T1/E1 trunk.
choices.A: Expressway-C provides encryption for Mobile and Remote Access but not for business-to-business communications.
choices.C: Expressway-E provides a perimeter network that separates the enterprise network from the Internet.

discussion.content:
C&D
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/solutions/CVD/Collaboration/enterprise/14/collbcvd/edge.html

Interworking — The capability to interconnect H.323-to-SIP calls for voice, video, and content sharing.
Boundary communications services — While Expressway-C sits in the corporate network, Expressway-E is in the enterprise DMZ and provides a distinct connection point for communication services between the enterprise network and the Internet.
Security — The capability to provide authentication and encryption for both mobile and remote access and business-to-business communications.

Selected Answer: CD
C and D is correct
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/solutions/CVD/Collaboration/enterprise/12x/120/collbcvd/edge.html#:~:text=The%20core%20components%20of%20the%20Collaboration%20Edge%20architecture,PSTN%20voice%20gateway%2C%20for%20direct%20audio%20PSTN%20connectivity

Selected Answer: CD
C and D.
Agree that should be CD. Answer A is wrong anyways cause you can setup the Expressways to provide B2B encryption. And the Expressway-E sits on the DMZ.

Selected Answer: CD
C and D

Selected Answer: CD
Correct Answers are C and D. From the first reference link:

The Expressway-C and Expressway-E pair performs the following functions:

Interworking — The capability to interconnect H.323-to-SIP calls for voice, video, and content sharing.
Boundary communications services — While Expressway-C sits in the corporate network, Expressway-E is in the enterprise DMZ and provides a distinct connection point for communication services between the enterprise network and the Internet.
Security — The capability to provide authentication and encryption for both mobile and remote access and business-to-business communications.

Hence, answer is C and D

comments.content: I am no so sure about C. Expressway E provides communications services between the enterprise and the Internet, but it is totally different to say that provides a "perimeter network". The only thing that provides a perimeter network is something called demilitarized zone (DMZ) that divides the corporate network and Intenet. Expressway E does not provides perimeter network, no way.

with A I've a problem that is clearly says Exp-C doesn't provide encryption for B2B calls. According to SRND for Edge infrastructure it is recommended to set media encryption on B2B traversal zone to best effort, as not all far end endpoint might support TLS. Answer says it doesn't provide encryption, where it is partial truth. Whereas for answer C I guess it again wording problem. Like you said it doesn't provide perimeter, but from all remaining answer this one sounds the most probably.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
Reference: "Understanding SBC's Comprehensive Guide to Designing, Deploying, Troubleshooting, and Maintaining CUBE Solutions", Chapter 14: Monitoring and Management

comments.content:
So,
A. es incorrect, there is no such a Real-Time SIP trunk utilization; rather is Trunk Capacity (when it is exceeded in the 90%) and Concurrent calls (in all of the platform, not just trunks).
D is incorrect. There is no Historical data here.
So B is related with Calls per second (CPS); and E is related with Trunk Status.
In order of these information, The more reasonable answers could be B. and E.

In order of the Generic Monitoring Baseline for Voice and Video Exceptions, we have:
**Trunk status.- When unreachable or in a down status.
**Trunk capacity.- > 90% of committed call quantity or total bandwidth.
**Feature license status.- < 90 days to expiration and > 90% of capacity utilized.
**Concurrent calls.- > 90% platform/license max.
**Calls per second.- > 90% platform/license max.
**Call admission control.- Upon exceeding value where calls will be rejected.
**Long-duration calls.- Upon call duration > 24 hours.
**DSP or media resource capacity.- > 90% capacity utilized.

And we have Generic Monitoring Baseline for Voice/Video Informational Logging:
**Calls per second (CPS).- The number of call setup requests per second.
**Concurrent calls.- The total number of active calls. Consider polling both platform totals as well as calls specific to each trunk/peer/adjacency.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
SIP Trunk Status is not available in SNMP (Just CLI)

questions.question_text: On an SNMP-managed network, Cisco Unified Border Element can be the managed device and an agent. Which two elements are essential elements of Cisco Unified Border Element monitoring currently available via SNMP? (Choose two.)

//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. When a call is received on Cisco Unified Border Element, from which IP does it allow a connection?

comments.content: Reference: Understanding SBC's Comprehensive Guide to Designing, Deploying, Troubleshooting, and Maintaining CUBE Solutions", Chapter 13: Security Threat Mitigation.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
CUBE has a specific feature that helps mitigate toll-fraud behavior. The out-of-the-box behavior is that CUBE will not accept call requests from any remote IP peer unless that peer has been explicitly defined in the system.
When a session target is defined in a dial peer, CUBE automatically adds to its trust list the IP address from the session target as an approved device for accepting call requests. Administrators can then add additional SIP source addresses to allow for SIP calls that may not be defined in a session target, such as IP addresses associated with SRV (DNS service) records or inbound sources for which there are no outbound dial peers configured for receiving outbound calls. Any incoming call requests from sources that aren’t defined using these two approaches will then be rejected with cause value 21.
In order of these information, correct answer is D.

Selected Answer: D
Correct is D
A - no 192.168.101.201 is not within ip address trusted list network 192.168.101.0 255.255.255.128 includes IPs 192.168.101.1 -192.168.101.127
B no 192.168.100.102 is not included in trusted list and not configured in dial-peer
C no 192.168.100.103 is not included in trusted list and not configured in dial-peer
D OK 192.168.102.102 is configured on dial-peer. Anything configured ion dial-peer is trusted by design.
